page.title: 01The Domesday Survey
page.content: Geologically, the area consists of chalk overlain with London clay, Reading Beds and Pebble Gravel.The N_S line of the Great North Road acts as a watershed between the Lea and Colne riverbasins. The saxon boundary results in a third of the area being in Middlesex and the rest in Hertfordshire. It was once wooded with tracts of common land. The earliest known occupation was in Mesolithic times. Villages developed at Northaw and Potters Bar, though neither was in the Domesday Day. Northaw is still a small village,but Little Heath developed in the 1880s,whilst the modern upper class area of Brookmans Park encroaches on the N.W. boundary. Potters Bar (pop.24,000) developed since 1930 as a commuter settlement for London, with some light industry.
